answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Hi Rachel,
We've been tracking several performance measures for each of those service areas for a couple of years now (on a monthly basis).  Here is a breakdown of what we measure:
Parks and Recreation:
Registered Program Participants (Youth/Adult)
Hours of Program Participation (Youth/Adult)
Volunteer Hours Worked
Special Events Conducted/Hosted/Sponsored
Facility Rentals
Staff Injuries
Documented Participant Injuries
Crimes Reported on Park Property
Customer Service:
Number of Payment Transactions (Broken Down by different methods of payment - ie walk in, webpay, autodraft, etc)
Billing Errors
Cash Drawer Over-under (cumulative for month)
Service Disconnections/Connections Transactions
Complaints Against Customer Service Reps
I think we still have a ways to go in refining our measures, but I think we're on the right track.  Along with these monthly measures (which tend to focus on outputs, rather than outcomes), we conduct biennial Citizen Surveys which help to gauge service outcomes.
Hope this helps - please feel free to follow up with me if you have any questions or want to discuss.
Sincerely,
Tom Quist

answers.author: Randy Webster
answers.text:
Hi Rachel, 
Here in Portland we have been reporting on performance measures for a while. Our parks performance measures are linked to the outcomes of the bureau's strategic plan, but not to the strategies and initiatives. Progress on strategies and initiatives is covered in a management report. 
No one measure is magic, there is no perfect key performance indicator - especially in public sector. We view performance measures in clusters, or constellations, that when viewed together tell a more complete and balanced story.  Good luck. 
Strategic Plan -  http://www.portlandonline.com/parks/index.cfm?a=261145&c=38306 
Annual Performance Report -  http://www.portlandonline.com/parks/index.cfm?a=380692&c=38306 
Feel free to call or email if you have any questions or would like to discuss ideas.

answers.author: Danielle Goodwin
answers.text:
Rachel,
I am currently an analyst for Center for Performance Measurement (CPM) here at ICMA. In case you are unfamiliar with CPM, CPM’s mission is to strive to assist local governments improve the quality, effectiveness and efficiency of public services through the collection, reporting and analysis of performance information.  We encourage the use of performance information in a positive, continuous-learning environment in order to foster organizational cultures that deliver results that matter.  CPM is able to achieve this mission by having participating jurisdictions fill out yearly service area templates (up to 18 service area templates) that are then cleaned and analyzed by staff to help jurisdictions see how they measure up  to similar jurisdictions, whether it be in size, location, climate, etc. The staff does not rank the jurisdictions based on performance, but instead we encourage jurisdictions to use the data given by to them by CPM and benchmark themselves against other communities.  With that being said, one of our service area templates is Parks and Recreation. 
For Parks and Recreation, one of the key performance indictors is the results from a citizen satisfaction survey. Currently, many of our participating jurisdictions take part in the National Citizen Survey, which is conducted by the National Research Center. The survey measures citizen satisfaction in four different ways. 
•   Citizen Ratings of Recreational Opportunities
•   Citizen Ratings of the Quality of Recreation Centers or Facilities
•   Citizen Ratings of the Quality of Recreation Programs or Classes
•   Citizen Ratings of the Quality of Parks in the Jurisdiction
Many jurisdictions find the National Citizen Survey or ANY citizen satisfaction survey highly valuable because they are able to measure how satisfied their citizens are with the services the jurisdiction is providing. These types of surveys allow jurisdictions to concentrate on areas where they would like to see citizens more satisfied, as dissatisfaction may indicate areas that need improvement. In addition to citizen satisfaction your jurisdiction would need to conjure up measures that help define “quality.” Some quality measures may be:
•   Number of playgrounds available in a park
•   Number of other facilities, like basketball courts, tennis courts, swimming pools, etc.
•   Number of hiking and walking paths
•   The conditions of the park, like the frequency of tree maintenance
There is a lot to think about when setting up benchmarking measurements in any service area. I would be more than happy to discuss this with you over the phone or through email if you would like.

answers.author: Gerald Young
answers.text:
Rachel,
In addition to the nationwide focus of the ICMA Center for Performance Measurement, we also have a number of state/regional consortia working on performance measurement issues. There are two such consortia in your area, in Central Ohio and Southwest Ohio. 
The Southwest Ohio consortium is already collecting performance data across the various CPM service areas (including parks, fire, police, highways, human resources, etc.), but is also in the preliminary stages of a discussion of the core measures the participating communities are most interested in comparing. 
I work with both consortia from my office in Granville. If you would like more information on upcoming activities within Ohio, please let me know.

author: Rachel Leininger
text: Our city is preparing to roll out performance measures for 2012.  We are hoping to gain a better understanding of the quality and efficiency of our services as well as have more data driven discussions with both coucil memebers and citizens.  Eventually we would like to benchmark ourselves with other communities.  So far the hardest part seems to be developing those key performance indicators that actually determines what you measure.  Has anyone else developed performance measures for their Parks and Recreation Departments or Customer Service Departments?  Were certain measures more helpful/reliable than others?  Any response is helpful as we embark on this journey.  Thanks!
title: Performance Measures: Parks and Recreation and Customer Service
